awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physiology of Long Distance Assimilate Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
The basis for life on earth is the conversion of solar energy into chemical energy by a process called photosynthesis that takes place in plants. The high energy containing end product of photosynthesis is sugar that has to be translocated, via a tissue called phloem, from the site of generation (in most cases leaves) to the sites of consumption and storage (stems, roots, fruits). Humans either consume energy rich plant tissues directly in the form of salads, cereals, vegetables etc., or indirectly via the consumption of meat, which was produced by animals consuming plants. The translocation of sugars within the phloem is a key mechanism in the production of high quality, high yield, and healthy food. For example, photosynthesis is actively reduced by the plant if export of sugars through the phloem is insufficient. Pests like aphids attack the phloem, insert their mouthparts into the tissue and feed on the sugar rich solution, which results in loss of production. Plant viruses travel through the phloem and cause severe damage to the plant. Despite the central role the phloem plays in plant performance and food production, the knowledge of the underlying processes of phloem loading and transport are poorly understood. This project will investigate the flow path of sugars through leaves, the entry or "loading" of sugars into the phloem and the distribution of sugars within the plant. Enhanced understanding of phloem loading and transport could lead to new strategies to protect plants from pests, to increase crop yield and to produce healthier food by reducing or eliminating the necessity for application of pesticides.

The goal of this award is to investigate physiological parameters of phloem loading and the physics of transport in plants with long phloem networks (vines and trees). Methods developed during previous awards will be used to generate cell and tissue-type based maps of leaves outlining turgor pressure and phloem flow patterns in different vein orders. In addition, the distribution of plasmodesmata between cells and tissues, and cell-to-cell conductivity from source cells to sieve tubes will be mapped. New systems to measure sieve tube turgor and flow velocity, as well as straightforward SEM based methods will be used to gather data on plasmodesmal frequencies and sieve plate structure. The relationship between plant size and source turgor pressure and phloem architecture in trees and vines with different loading types will also be investigated. This will allow current models of phloem transport to be re-parameterized so as to reflect better the hydraulic architecture of the pathway for photoassimilate transport through the plant. This award will also bring together researchers specializing in plant cell biology and vascular transport, and support education and training for a postdoctoral researcher and graduate students, as well as engage undergraduates in research and provide opportunities for high-school students and teachers to learn about the transport of photoassimilates in plants.

por.por_cntn:
Energy-rich molecules produced by photosynthesis feed our planet. The majority of the products of photosynthesis need to be transported from their site of generation in the plant to distant organs for growth, energy conversion, and storage. Photoassimilate translocation in plants takes place in the sieve tubes of the phloem. Translocated photosynthesis products build our primary food sources including fruits, grains, tubers, and more. Through consumption by animals, secondary food sources such as meat and eggs are generated. The high content of energy-rich substances attracts phloem-sucking insects which transmit diseases that utilize the phloem to colonize the plant. Pathogens such as viruses pose minor threats when infecting single cells or spreading within a single leaf. But once the pathogen enters the sieve tube network, systemic infection and major losses in productivity are unavoidable. Viruses, phytoplasmas, and bacterial pathogens cause epidemics in all agronomically important crops. Due to the lack of alternative measures, destruction of infected plants is usually the only option to confine epidemics. Pathogens destroy between 20% and 40% of crop yields worldwide and cause an annual loss of $40 billion in the US alone. Thus, the phloem represents a central component of utmost importance for agriculture. But still the phloem is the least understood major plant tissue.

In the 1930s, German forestry scientist Ernst Münch developed the pressure-flow hypothesis to explain the biophyscal basis of fluid transport through the phloem. According to Münch, a sugar-rich sap is loaded into the sieve tubes in photosynthesizing organs, generating high intracellular pressure that pushes the sieve tube contents away and toward non-photosynthesizing organs that consume the photoassimilates. This hypothesis has been questioned on numerous occasions, especially in large, woody plants. Intriguingly, parts of the early disagreements about the ‘Münch hypothesis’ were fueled by the reluctance of botanists dedicated to pure science to accept mechanistic concepts put forward by applied scientists like Münch, as we have shown in a recent review article.  

Over the past two decades, we have developed a number of methods for studying phloem function. In this grant period, we have applied these methods to investigate how products of photosynthesis are loaded into the phloem and how long-distance transport is accomplished in large plants such as trees and vines. We have installed microscopes in the canopy of trees to measure relevant physical parameters, most importantly the hydrostatic pressure within sieve tubes, and collected samples for high-resolution anatomical studies. We demonstrated that growing trees adjust the structure and physiology of their phloem tissues to compensate for increasing tube length in elongating organs. These adjustments accord with the predictions of the pressure-flow hypothesis. Our work provides strong support for Münch’s ideas.

In the course of our studies on phloem transport in trees, we structurally and functionally characterized bodies formed of so-called phloem-specific proteins for the first time in a woody species. Furthermore, our improved understanding of the physiological and developmental integration of phloem function in large plants triggered a revision of our views on the origin of non-photosynthetic compounds such as mRNAs, which are transported in the phloem over long distances. Most recently, we developed a diffusion-based micro-injection methodology that significantly reduces artifacts induced by conventional methods; a manuscript describing the method has been submitted for publication.
